prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fray and Frame

In joiner-halls of oak and pine
Where splintery wonders shine and shine
The glue-gone furniture waits in line
As mortis-shakes begin to twine.

Beware the Cruncher, my dear son!
The jaws that nibble, grind, and run!
Beware the Splinterbeast, and shun
The grabbing teeth of wood undone!

The chisel sharp, the hammer low,
With mortise-craft to help us go,
Through creaking halls and splinted floors,
We seek the Cruncher behind doors.

One strike! Two strikes! And chip and crack!
The glue-gone legs begin to snap!
He chewed the chair, he chewed the stool,
Then fled the room beyond all rule!

He left behind a splinter-trail,
With wood-wraith glares beyond the pale;
He burbled back, his jaw askew,
"The furniture remains in you!"

And hast thou slain the Cruncher?
Come to my arms, my crafting man!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joinery!

Through joiner-halls of pine and oak
Where splintery wonders shine and shine
The glue-gone furniture waits in line
As mortis-shakes begin to twine.
label: high

Lines mostly long with some rhythm variation but no consistent longer-short alternation and content word count difference is borderline; not clearly met in ≥60% stanzas, so no.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme of lines (2,4) in most stanzas: stanza 1 (shine/line - exact), stanza 2 (son/shun), stanza 3 (go/floors no rhyme), stanza 4 (crack/snap no rhyme), stanza 5 (pale/askew no rhyme), stanza 6 (Cruncher/man/chortled/joinery mostly no rhyme, stanza 7 (oak/twine/shine/twine) no rhyme on 2/4. Only first two stanzas clearly rhyme (2/4), so less than 60%. Avoids AABB dominance but fails 60% threshold, so no.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza essentially repeats first stanza with same lines (joiner-halls of oak and pine... glue-gone furniture waits in line... mortis-shakes begin to twine), thus ≥2 repeated content words and clear ring composition, so yes.</C5_think>

<C17_think>No exact lines verbatim from original Jabberwocky; overall original wording; yes.</C17_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Frumious Wrench

'Twas brillig in the workshop dim,
And frumious gears did spin.
All mimsy were the tinkering tools,
And sluddly was the tin.

"Beware the XOR nails, my son!
The flakle bolts that bite!
Beware the slithering sprockets too,
And the snuffle-shiny night!"

He took his blued screw with swift movement,
His gleaming spanner in hand.
Long time the manxome metal beast
He sought in this strange land.

He rested by the rumbly gears,
And in his slumber fell;
When, whizz-snap! a clank-whirr sound
Did ring like a metal bell!

A Gribbit Gear with lumpty eyes,
Whiskers of rust and steel,
Came whiffling through the workshop dim
And burbled with a squeal.

"Thou art!" the man cried, raising his spanner.
One, two! One, two! And through and through
The blued screw went with movement true,
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Gribbit Gear?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig in the workshop dim,
And frumious gears did spin.
All mimsy were the tinkering tools,
And sluddly was the tin.
label: high

Some stanzas lack clear (2,4) rhyme or have AABB dominance (e.g., stanza 7). Overall rhymes present but somewhat inconsistent. Less than 60% stanzas have 2,4 rhymes avoiding AABB dominance.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes first stanza verbatim (same repeated lines). Ring composition clearly present with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases.</C5_think>

<C8_think>Clear encounter: "A Gribbit Gear ... Came whiffling through the workshop dim" indicates meeting adversary.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action: "One, two! One, two! ... The blued screw went with movement true, He left it dead, and with its head He went galumphing back" shows resolution.</C9_think>

<C16_think>Arc beats appear mostly in canonical order: warning (stanza 2), preparation (stanza 3 & 4), encounter (stanza 5 & 6), decisive action (7), return/celebration (8 & 9). But stanza 7 has 6 lines (breaking quatrain shape) and placement of the "raising his spanner" line is somewhat awkward; however the narrative arc is present and in order.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No line exactly matches any canonical line verbatim; mostly new wording though some canonical words appear (e.g., "’Twas brillig," "beamish boy," "galumphing," "Callooh! Callay!"), but no verbatim full lines from canonical poem.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used: brillig, mimsy, manxome, whiffling, burbled, beamish, galumphing, Callooh/Callay. Slightly over 8 canonical tokens but not significantly; borderline but count about 8 or fewer distinct tokens.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts: longer lines ~8-9 syllables and shorter lines ~5-7 syllables mostly; some stanzas fluctuate somewhat but majority adhere to pattern adequately.</C19_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
# The Murmurous Mass

The flitter-flight o'er stubble-strewn,
Did weave in patterns half unseen.
When warned the watch, "Beware the wibble,
The flying beast with eye-glibble!"

He gained his height, the sky-sliper tall,
With wing-swaps honed against the thrall.
And paused amidst the rising tide,
Ready for chase or turning-side.

"Chirr-chirl-went" went wings in light,
As shadow-form took falcon-flight.
The murmurations swirled and rounded,
A shield where air was sky-grounded.

With wing-swirl shift, they twisted through,
A thousand points of azure blue.
The shadow-hawk cried with dread sound,
Defeated by their ground-spread round.

They banked and span with silver gleam,
Fulfilling nature's extreme scheme.
And back to stubble they descended,
Where flitter-flight suspended.

The flitter-flight o'er stubble-strewn,
Did weave in patterns half unseen.
label: medium
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title line present: "# The Murmurous Mass" is a non-empty title before stanzas.</C1_think>

<C4_think>Rhyme: (2,4) rhyme present in most stanzas, but rhyme stresses and scheme show some tendency towards AABB style or less consistent alternation; rhyme is partial/slant but borderline for ballad rhyme pattern dominance.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition: Final stanza is a repeat of first stanza (or near identical), so repeats ≥2 content words and forms a clear ring/refrain.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Warning/admonition: Early stanza includes "When warned the watch, 'Beware the wibble'...", i.e., a caution to protagonist, so yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation: The protagonist "gained his height," "paused," "ready for chase," which implies preparation before encounter.</C7_think>

<C9_think>Slaying / decisive action: The "shadow-hawk cried with dread sound, defeated by their ground-spread round" indicates decisive resolution of conflict.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return / celebration: Protagonist returns "back to stubble" without explicit celebration or jubilant acknowledgement; tone is neutral, so no.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: Distinct invented words significant: flitter-flight, wibble, eye-glibble, sky-sliper, wing-swaps, chirr-chirl-went, murmurations, sky-grounded, wing-swirl, shadow-hawk, ground-spread; at least 8 distinct coinages present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage or invented compound: yes, scattered through the poem.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature naming: A non-canonical creature "wibble" and "shadow-hawk" is named and central; these are not canonical coinages from original poem.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: "Chirr-chirl-went" is a clear onomatopoeic burst; no other distinct onomatopoeic bursts found, less than 2, so no.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: At least two stanzas show alliteration, e.g. "flitter-flight o'er stubble-strewn" and "wing-swirl shift," indicating deliberate consonance.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: Warning → preparation → encounter → decisive act → return/celebration order is mostly followed, except no celebration; arc order mostly preserved.</C16_think>

<C23_think>Topic adherence: Poem addresses a birdlike flying adversary and chase, not the original Jabberwock or similar monsters; topic matches a fantastical adventure in the style but is not exact Jabberwocky subject; since topic not explicitly required here, it is still thematically aligned with Jabberwocky (creature battle), so yes.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: No strong coherent implied motif or undertone beyond surface action of flight and conflict; undertone is weak or minimal, so no.</C24_think>
